textos_fuente.text: SOLD OUT / Orange Blossom Opry Matinee : Weirsdale, FL | George Strait Trib. top of page George Strait Tribute Strait Country Tribute TRIBUTE CALENDAR BIO VIDEO PHOTOS CONTACT More Use tab to navigate through the menu items. Howard Decker; the nation's top tribute act to King George Strait Join Us SOLD OUT / Orange Blossom Opry Matinee : Weirsdale, FL Sat, Sep 14 | The Orange Blossom Opry Don’t miss this incredible matinee opportunity to watch Howard Decker perform with his incredible voice and stage presence, duplicating the legend himself, George Strait. You won’t be disappointed! Registration is closed See other events Time & Location Sep 14, 2024, 3:30 PM EDT The Orange Blossom Opry , SE 138th Ter, Florida 32195, USA About the event Tickets Now on Sale! The Orange Blossom Opry 16439 SE 138th Ter, Weirsdale, FL (352) 821-1201 office@obopry.com Show More Share this event George Strait Tribute Strait Country Tribute TRIBUTE CALENDAR BIO VIDEO PHOTOS CONTACT More Use tab to navigate through the menu items. ©2023 by George Strait Tribute - Strait Country Tribute . SUBSCRIBE for UPDATES BOOK a SHOW REQUEST a SHOW GET your TICKETS Decker's Favorite 5 Words "Show Me to the Stage" Music and Entertainment Websites by Nashville Web Design .BIZ All in tribute to King George and the entire team that built his legacy in country music! Click to the real Georg Strait too: George Strait Website :: George Strait Hall of Fame bottom of page

Leadership - OPB Sept. 11, 2025 contribute now About / Leadership Senior Leadership Rachel Smolkin, President and CEO Rachel Smolkin became president and CEO of OPB in 2024. She is responsible for leading the strategic direction and overall mission of the organization. Prior to OPB, she served as senior vice president of global news for CNN Digital, overseeing breaking news, politics and Washington, U.S. and international teams across the network’s digital platforms worldwide. She came to CNN in 2014 to build the network’s coverage of Washington, politics and elections into a top digital politics brand. Before coming to CNN, she served in leadership and editing roles at Politico, USA Today and American Journalism Review magazine. Rachel has an MBA from the University of Virginia Darden School of Business, where she attended the global executive program as a Batten Media Fellow alongside her work at CNN. She completed the Sulzberger Executive Leadership program at Columbia University and holds a bachelor’s degree in political science from Brown University. Contact Rachel at ceo@opb.org . Jason Potts, Senior Vice president, Chief Content Officer Jason Potts is OPB’s senior vice president and chief content officer, joining the organization in 2025. He is responsible for shaping OPB’s audience-centered storytelling through our journalism and strong partnerships around the region. Prior to OPB, he led business development and content strategy at Scripps News, driving audience growth and engagement. He conceived the popular Scripps News Viewer Hotline and Viewer Spotlight segments and led production teams to create award-winning news and documentary programming. Before Scripps, Potts managed experimental partnerships and internal innovations at the Disney-ABC Owned Television Stations group. Jason has received multiple accolades for his work, including a New England Emmy, National Headliner Award and a GLAAD Award. He received a BA in English from Yale University, an MBA from the UCLA Anderson School of Management and a certificate in generative AI from the University of Chicago. Contact Jason at cco@opb.org . Cheryl Ikemiya, Senior Vice President and Chief Development Officer Cheryl Ikemiya is OPB’s senior vice president and chief development officer. She leads a team of development professionals, focused on building relationships that provide revenue to power our public service mission. Our comprehensive development program builds support from members, foundation and individual philanthropy, and sponsors from corporate and non-profit sectors. With a background in non-profit management in performing arts, culture and history, Cheryl began at OPB in 2005 and moved into her current role in 2015. Contact Cheryl at cdo@opb.org . Lisa Garcia Grace, Senior Vice President, Programming and Audience Engagement Lisa Garcia Grace is senior vice president of programming and audience engagement. Her team connects OPB’s content with diverse audiences, fostering meaningful connections that inspire, inform and engage. Lisa joined OPB in 2016 and moved into her current role in 2022. She has worked in public media and nonprofit management for 20 years in a variety of roles including programming, engagement, development and communications. She has a bachelor’s degree in Journalism from the University of Colorado, is a graduate of the Kellog Media Executive Leadership program at Northwestern University and is a 2025 Sulzberger Executive Leadership Fellow. Contact Lisa at programming@opb.org . Stacy Tumarkin, Senior Vice President, Chief Operating Officer Stacy Tumarkin joined OPB as senior vice president and chief operating officer in 2025. Stacy is responsible for keeping the organization running smoothly, leading key operational departments and teams including finance and accounting, people and culture, technology, and legal to create cohesive internal systems and to facilitate the delivery of journalism to audiences across platforms. She possesses a broad background in executive leadership, having held COO, CFO, and Head of People roles across a diverse range of industries and markets. Prior to joining OPB, Stacy served as founding COO and CFO at Kubecost, an infrastructure technology startup that was acquired by IBM in 2024. Her nonprofit experience includes spending nearly two years running digital content at The Himalayan Institute, an international humanitarian organization focused on promoting holistic healing and yoga. Tumarkin holds an MBA from the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, and a BA in Business Economics from UC Santa Barbara. Contact Stacy at stumarkin@opb.org . Shayna Schlosberg, Vice President, Community Connections Shayna Schlosberg is OPB’s vice president of community connections. She develops and oversees initiatives that ensure OPB and KMHD are representative of the communities we serve across all aspects of our work. In her role, Shayna drives the strategy, vision and implementation of OPB and KMHD’s community representation and inclusion practices. Shayna joined OPB in 2022, and prior to her role here, she served as the Director of Strategy and Operations for Women of Color in the Arts. Shayna also has served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Armenia. Contact Shayna at equityleader@opb.org . Kim Locke, Chief of Staff Kim Locke serves as OPB’s Chief of Staff. In this role she brings teams together to shape and achieve strategic, operational, and cultural change. Prior to joining OPB in 2018, Kim worked in global technology and software companies before joining Nike’s global sales business operations team. With a lifelong interest in helping people succeed she holds a BA in Sociology from UC Santa Barbara and is a Prosci certified change practitioner. Contact Kim at klocke@opb.org . Holly Bullock-Denniston, Vice President, People and Culture Holly Bullock-Denniston is OPB’s vice president of people and culture (P&C). She has been at OPB since 1999, serving in volunteer management and HR roles. As the leader of the P&C department since 2020, she ensures OPB’s culture is inclusive and welcoming so that staff belong and thrive. Her team combines a systems approach and personalized interactions to optimize individual employee experience while maintaining legal and regulatory compliance. Holly has a master’s degree in public administration focusing on nonprofit management from Portland State University and a bachelor’s degree in planning, public policy and management focusing on social policy from the University of Oregon. She has held both the SHRM-SP and SPHR credentials. She was an adjunct professor at Portland State University in the MPA program, teaching nonprofit HR management classes. She has also served as an AmeriCorps/VISTA volunteer in Philadelphia. Contact Holly at people@opb.org . Jan Heskiss, CPA, Chief Financial Officer and Assistant Secretary-Treasurer Jan Heskiss is the chief financial officer of OPB, overseeing the financial operations of the company. Prior to joining OPB in 2001, Jan served in senior financial roles at organizations in various sectors, including nonprofit (Pace Center for Girls, Florida), broadcasting (KGW-TV, KINK-FM, KGW-AM, Oregon) and public accounting (KPMG, Oregon and Arizona). Contact Jan at cfo@opb.org . Rebecca Morris, Vice President and General Counsel Rebecca Morris is a vice president and general counsel for OPB. In her role, she oversees all OPB legal matters and leads an in-house legal team that works across the organization to solve problems, assess and mitigate risks, facilitate transactions, assist with regulatory compliance, manage litigation, and develop sound policies and procedures. Rebecca has been at OPB since 2006. Prior to that, she served as assistant general counsel at Thirteen/WNET in New York City. Contact Rebecca at legal@opb.org . Jonathan Newsome, Interim Chief Technology Officer and Vice President, Technology Jonathan Newsome currently serves as OPB’s interim chief technology officer and vice president of technology. In this role, he provides strategic leadership and vision for OPB’s technology department, ensuring the infrastructure supports seamless engagement with audiences, no matter the platform or location. His focus is ensuring that OPB’s systems empower staff and foster innovation across content creation and distribution. Jonathan’s path to public media began after his time at the Savannah College of Art and Design, launching his career as a musician and recording engineer. He entered public media in 2005 with Live Wire! Radio, and joined OPB in 2010 as the technical director for Think Out Loud. Since 2014, he has played a key role in OPB’s Engineering and Technology teams, helping to shape the organization’s technical evolution. Contact Jonathan at cto@opb.org . OPB Board of Directors Chair: John Topanga ( email ) Vice chair: Curtis Robinhold Secretary/Treasurer: Peter Platt Members: Rukaiyah Adams, Karen Anderson, Jesse Beason, Nils D. Christoffersen, Roger Cooke, Graciela Gomez Cowger, Rebecca DeCesaro, Elisa Dozono, Colin Evans, Kathleen George, Margaret Kirkpatrick, Sandy Rowe, Carla Salazar, Lee Weinstein, Sheryl WuDunn; Lisa Skari, ex-officio voting member; Rachel Smolkin, ex-officio nonvoting member Community Advisory Board (CAB) Members: Lesley Albert, John Bloss, Linda Castillo, Sokho Eath, Alex Garfield, Connie Green, Stephen Green, Andréa Guedes, Tracey Lam, Pat Lynch, Katy Nesbitt, Julie Nist, Melanie Potter, Nikki Pritchard, John Riutta, Tamara Russell, Rick Short, Teresa St. Martin, Sam Stites OPB Board Liaison: Rad Probst ( email ) THANKS TO OUR SPONSOR: Become a Sponsor Stand with OPB and protect independent journalism for everyone. We use cookies on our website to give you the most relevant experience by remembering your preferences and repeat visits. By clicking “Accept”, you consent to the use of ALL the cookies. Cookie Settings Accept Manage consent Close Privacy Overview This website uses cookies to improve your experience while you navigate through the website. Out of these, the cookies that are categorized as necessary are stored on your browser as they are essential for the working of basic functionalities of the website. We also use third-party cookies that help us analyze and understand how you use this website. These cookies will be stored in your browser only with your consent. You also have the option to opt-out of these cookies. But opting out of some of these cookies may affect your browsing experience. Necessary Necessary Always Enabled Necessary cookies are absolutely essential for the website to function properly. These cookies ensure basic functionalities and security features of the website, anonymously. The cookie is used to store the user consent for the cookies in the category "Analytics". cookielawinfo-checkbox-functional 11 months The cookie is set by GDPR cookie consent to record the user consent for the cookies in the category "Functional". cookielawinfo-checkbox-necessary 11 months This cookie is set by GDPR Cookie Consent plugin. The cookie is used to store the user consent for the cookies in the category "Performance". viewed_cookie_policy 11 months The cookie is set by the GDPR Cookie Consent plugin and is used to store whether or not user has consented to the use of cookies. It does not store any personal data. Functional Functional Functional cookies help to perform certain functionalities like sharing the content of the website on social media platforms, collect feedbacks, and other third-party features. Performance Performance Performance cookies are used to understand and analyze the key performance indexes of the website which helps in delivering a better user experience for the visitors. Analytics Analytics Analytical cookies are used to understand how visitors interact with the website. These cookies help provide information on metrics the number of visitors, bounce rate, traffic source, etc. Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement cookies are used to provide visitors with relevant ads and marketing campaigns. These cookies track visitors across websites and collect information to provide customized ads. Others Others Other uncategorized cookies are those that are being analyzed and have not been classified into a category as yet. A different privacy policy and terms of service will apply. 352-821-1201 About Us: The Orange Blossom Opry is a family oriented, smoke free, alcohol free, country music showcase located in the small Central Florida community of Weirsdale. It is located in what was originally the Weirsdale School Gymnasium. The gymnasium was converted several years ago to serve as an opry house. The Opry first opened as "Haw Hee's", then became the "Weirsdale Opry" and finally "The Orange Blossom Opry". The current owners, Estelle and Earl Benson , are in their third season and the Opry Cast , or, as they are also known, the "Orange Blossom Opry Band", has presented a variety of musical styles, mostly traditional country and Bluegrass, and its own special brand of humor for the past seven years. Mailing Address: The Orange Blossom Opry PO Box 979 Weirsdale FL 32195 Report an Issue Please use "Flag This Place" to alert us about content that is inappropriate or needs immediate attention. Nothing you submit will be shared with other site visitors. OKR board - iObeya Skip to content Product Solution Pricing Resources Partner Contact us Request a demo English Français Product Solution Pricing Resources Partner Product Digital Obeyas for hybrid teams Digitize Lean and Agile systems Best in class integrations Enterprise-grade security Product highlights Discover the full range of iObeya features Product Digital Obeyas for hybrid teams Digitize Lean and Agile systems Best in class integrations Enterprise-grade security Product highlights Discover the full range of iObeya features Solution By Use case Lean Project Management Agile at Scale Lean Manufacturing By Industry Pharmaceutical Defense – Aerospace Logistics Energy iObeya for the pharmaceutical industry Discover many templates Solution By Use case Lean Project Management Agile at Scale Lean Manufacturing By Industry Pharmaceutical Defense – Aerospace Logistics Energy iObeya for the pharmaceutical industry Discover many templates Resources Blog Customers testimonials Events Discover our features Product highlights Templates Resource Center 12 June 2025 – Massy FRANCE iObeya User Exchange 2025 Resources Blog Customers testimonials Events Discover our features Product highlights Templates Resource Center 12 June 2025 – Massy FRANCE iObeya User Exchange 2025 Contact Us Request a demo English Français Home Templates OKR board OKR board Get this template What is an OKR board in iObeya? An OKR board is a Visual Management tool that allows you to track and display the Objectives and Key Results (OKR) of an organization, a team, or an individual. OKRs are widely used for performance management and goal setting. An OKR board is a physical or digital board where the main objectives of a company, team, or project, as well as the key results that need to be achieved to meet these objectives, are displayed. OKRs are designed to be specific, measurable, ambitious, relevant, and time-bound. They provide a clear framework for aligning efforts and priorities within an organization. Why use an OKR board? An OKR board allows you to track real-time progress toward the achievement of objectives and key results. It helps teams stay focused on what matters most, prioritize tasks, and ensure that everyone is aligned to achieve the company’s goals. The use of an OKR board offers several benefits for companies and organizations, including: Aligning teams with common objectives and key results; Transparency via OKR boards that make objectives and progress visible; Prioritizing tasks and projects based on the most important objectives; Holding each team member accountable for achieving their own objectives; Real-time tracking of progress toward set objectives. OKR boards facilitate quick adjustments when needed; Informed decision-making through OKR boards that provide a solid foundation with clear objectives and ongoing data collected on progress. In summary, OKR boards are well-suited for operational performance management and promote goal achievement within organizations. They enhance the productivity and efficiency of organizations that use them. Who uses an OKR board? OKR boards are used by both Lean and Agile teams. The Lean method and OKR boards share a common aim toward continuous improvement and transparency, but they differ in their primary focus and specific tools. OKR boards focus on objectives, while Lean focuses on the processes that support the achievement of these objectives ( including Kaizen or PDCA cycles). Combining these two approaches promotes operational excellence. The Agile method and OKR boards have in common their aim toward agility, alignment with objectives, transparency, iteration, and continuous improvement. Combining these two approaches allows for the flexibility and visibility of OKR boards while integrating Agile practices for project and product management. This contributes to creating an organizational culture focused on agility, performance, and goal achievement. How to set up an OKR board in iObeya To organize an OKR in your digital Obeya, follow these steps: Enter your room, then click ‘Configure’ the room at the bottom right of the screen. Add a blank board to your room. Select the OKR background from the background catalog. In the tool dock define a new set of Notes as Major goal / Objective / Key results, add Free text . Your board is now ready to be used. Expert tips on using an OKR board To maximize the effectiveness of OKR boards, here are expert tips: Take the time to properly train stakeholders on the OKR methodology and how it works. The OKR board should involve all hierarchical levels of th organization, from operational staff to top management. Management commitment is crucial to achieving expected results. Formulate each objective in a concise sentence with clear, achievable, and measurable key results. Limit yourself to 3 or 5 main objectives per period. This will help your teams stay focused on what really matters. Ensure that objectives and key results are aligned with the company’s mission and vision. This way, each team’s efforts remain aligned with the organization’s overall goals. Regularly update OKR boards, ideally on a weekly basis, to reflect actual team progress. Review and adjust your OKRs as needed to maximize the impact of actions and remain agile. Share the OKR board with all stakeholders. This transparency will promote accountability and alignment. Encourage a culture of learning by sharing experiences, especially when an OKR is not achieved. Failure is an opportunity for improvement. Feel free to customize these tips based on the specific needs of your organization! About OPB - OPB Sept. 11, 2025 contribute now About / About OPB Our Mission Connecting people across Oregon and the Pacific Northwest through the power of a shared story. We are an independent, nonprofit media organization serving communities across Oregon and the Pacific Northwest. Powered by the generous support of members, OPB connects people through trusted journalism that is freely accessible to everyone. At OPB, we believe stories have power. The power to educate. To entertain. To inform and enlighten. A story, told well, can help us feel a deeper connection with our neighbors and to the wider world. For more than 100 years , Oregon Public Broadcasting (OPB) has called this region home and shared stories that have shaped our region’s history. We’ve brought stories from around the world and around the corner into people’s homes, in their car, and wherever they go. Guided by a pursuit of truth, a spirit of curiosity, with equity and public service at the center of our work, we deliver in-depth, fact-driven coverage of politics , science and the environment , arts and culture , education and more. Because of the financial support of our members , our growing journalism operation is one of the largest in the Pacific Northwest. Our team of award-winning , dedicated reporters, producers and editors report on stories across the region — from southern Washington to southern Oregon. OPB’s journalism and programs seek to connect people across communities and go deeper into what makes this region special. We seek diverse voices to help us tell the stories that define who we all are, what we do, where we live and where we’re going. Tiffany Camhi, higher education reporter at Oregon Public Broadcasting, conducting an interview in Portland, April 7, 2022.
